Luigi Ferraris, Executive Vice President, Administration, Planning and Control
Francesco Starace, Head of Domestic Sales Division
Gianfilippo Mancini, Chief Operating Officer of Generation & Energy Management Division
Livio Gallo, Chief Operating Officer of Infrastructure and Networks Division
Carlo Tamburi, Head of International Division
Andrea Brentan, Chief Operating Officer of Iberia and Latin America Division
Luca Torchia, Head of Investor Relations

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Presentation of 2008-2012 Strategic Plan. I am very pleased to be announcing today the very strong set of 2007 results. These numbers demonstrate the value we are creating from our strategy. Last year has been a transformational year for Enel with the acquisition of Endesa and the Russian assets. We will therefore be presenting to you today in detail the strategy and targets we have for the new Group over the next five year.

The next five years for Enel will center around three priorities. Consolidating and integrating the new Group, delivering growth from this new platform, while maintaining a stable and secure financial position, but before we review the 2007 results and go into more detail for each division, let me outline the headline numbers which demonstrate all this.

Next chart: well, during the next five years we expect to generate an operating cash flow of €63 billion. This comes from a cumulative EBITDA of €74.5 billion, generated by international growth, particularly from Endesa and the Russian investments, the ongoing efficiency programs and our organic growth in Italy and international.

During this period we'll also seek to maximize the value of our existing assets through a carefully targeted program on non-strategic asset disposals, as well as prioritization of renewables with limited potential add-on investments in our existing geographies.

We estimate that the net cash effect of these sales and investments will be in the range of €11/15 billion cash in. This cash flow and funds from portfolio optimization will allow us to deliver growth through organic investments of €37 billion, to pay debt service of 14 billion and maintain a dividend of €0.49 per share throughout the period with the two years installment payments.

This will total a €15 billion of dividends outflow, which will move our payout ratio from 76% in 2007 down to 59% in 2012. And overall this will leave us 8 to €12 billion which will be applied to debt reduction to ensure that Enel's balance sheet is both efficient and secure and to support a stable A rating on our debts.

As you can see the outlook for Enel is very positive. Following the transformational acquisition of 2007, we are now entering a period of strong organic growth. We are launching a careful targeted CapEx program to drive this growth, particularly through renewable innovative technologies. We will continue to extract ongoing value out of the core markets, particularly in Italy and Spain. We are committed to deliver an EPS CAGR of 10% for the period 2007-2012 and to achieve a debt level in the range of 45 to 49 billion by 2012.
I will now hand it over to Luigi for giving you the details on the 2007 results. Luigi?

Thank you, Fulvio. Good morning ladies and gentlemen. I am very pleased to show you a very strong set of financial results. As you will hear from Fulvio's presentation, we completed our transformation process into an integrated international energy player and the numbers are reflecting this.

First, on chart number five, I am going to give you a snapshot of some relevant financial highlights. Then I will take you through our 2007 financial results. The numbers you see show an overall growing performance driven by all of our divisions as you will see later in the presentation. In particular, from the underlying depositing contribution of Endesa which passed delivery value into our group.
Now, on chart number six, our overall financial results. Starting from EBIT, down to net income. As you can see, the EBIT increased by 20%, thanks to the EBITDA improvement.

Our net financial charges amount to €900 million. This is the net effect of the following. First, higher interest charges for almost €1.4 billion mainly due to the increase in net debt position following the acquisition of Endesa, and the first 37% stake in OGK-5. Second, higher financial income for €300 million mainly dividend coming from Endesa. Third, higher income resulting from the fair value valuation of Acciona put option for €136 million. And fourth, other positive items for €51 million mainly due to risk management activities.

Coming to taxes. Our tax rate decreases from 40% to 30% mainly thanks to the impacts of the deferred tax asset and liabilities and the new fiscal law in Italy. Moreover, group net income grew by 31% and our cost of debt as of 2007, is equal to an average of 5.1%.

Now on chart number 7, our overall financial results starting from the EBITDA evolution. EBITDA increases by 25% compared to the same period of the last year with a strong growth of all the operational divisions and in particular on the international division with the consolidation of Endesa, which accounts for €1.2 billion as you will find detailed in the following charts.

Next of the above mentioned contribution of Endesa, full year 2007 EBITDA would be up almost 10% versus last year. I would like to remind you that according to the international accounting standard 2007 EBITDA figure does not include the contribution of Endesa Europe recorded as discontinued operation, which amounts to almost €200 million.

Let's move on to the individual business areas starting with chart number eight on the Domestic Market Division. EBITDA totals €325 million versus €167 million last year. This is the net effect of the following. First, the increase of €108 million in the electricity regulated market. Second the increase of €132 million in the contribution of the free markets. Thanks to the following.

Higher gas margins for €80 million, basically due to higher volume sold and to the positive FX for €26 million of the remodulation of the gas tariffs to end users set by the regulator. Higher electivity margins for €52 million, basically due to higher volume sold and third other and other non-recurring items of minus €82 million, which includes cost of customer acquisition and the electricity authority fine.

Moving now to chart number nine or Domestic Generation and Energy Management, EBITDA totaled €3541 million representing an increase of €384 million versus 2006. On the positive side we record, first the improvement of €328 million in the generation margin thanks to the following.

€307 million due to the contribution of unit margins driven by the positive effects of the improvements of the fuel mix and by higher revenues from ancillary services, which more than offset lower volumes, minus €75 million of energy trading activities due to lower volumes coupled with lower prices and €96 million lower provision for early retirement incentives versus last year.

Second the positive impact of €103 million for the fair value of bilateral contracts with a single buyer. The above mentioned improvement has been partially offset by the reduction of €47 million in non-recurring items totally recorded in the first quarter of 2006.

Lets' now have a quick look at the fuel cost evolution on chart number ten. As you can see in this chart, our average fuel cost per megawatt hour has decreased by about 5% versus 2006, while our average unit revenues stand at €74.4 per megawatt hour versus 70.6 of last year. This is clearly boosting our total unit margin by more than 16% versus last year. These numbers of course are not including contribution of ancillary services which would go on top of them.

Moving on to chart number 11, or Domestic Infrastructure and Networks Division, EBITDA totaled €3,726 million representing an increase of €300 million versus 2006. This takes us up substantially the effect of the following. First, the improvements of €333 million in the electricity business mainly thanks to higher energy margin for more than €100 million strong cost saving actions for €80 million, lower provision for early retirement incentives for €142 million.

And second, the increase in the gas business of €61 million, mainly due to higher gas margin and cost savings. The above mentioned improvement has been partially offset by the negative impacts of non-recurring items related to the capital gain for last year disposal of the Modena network.

Moving now to chart number 12, or International operation, well EBITDA totaled €2,380 million, representing an increased of almost €1.5 billion versus last year. This is mainly due to the effect of the consolidation of Endesa in the fourth quarter. The main contribution refers to the following, Endesa positive impact of €1.2 billion for the 70% consolidation of the company. This amount is split into the Iberia area for €691 million and into the Americas area for €531 million, in Centrel, a strong contribution of Slovenske Elektrarne for €198 million.

Let me just say a few words about, in particular Slovenske Elektrarne. Full year 2007 EBITDA of this company is equal to €580 million boosted by higher domestic energy prices, higher volumes and cost reduction. In South Eastern Europe, an increase of €6 million and in the Americas net of the contribution of Endesa, we recorded €42 million increase mainly due to the positive performance of the Group's operation in South America for the consolidation of the Panama assets. This more than offsets lower contribution in North America due to a positive one-off item recorded in 2006.

Moving on to chart number 13, a quick look at EBITDA of the Services and Holding area, which stands at €51 million or minus €300 million versus last year. This is the net effect of the following, first lower margin on imports for €240 million largely in line with our projections, mainly due to lower volumes imported and lower prices. Second non-recurring items, which decreased by €23 million and other items for €45 million.

Also moving to Chart number 14, let me just give you a snapshot about our renewable areas. Well, let me tell you that the numbers reported in this chart includes our Italian wind, geothermal, mini-hydro and solar operation and all our international renewable activities with the exception of larger hydro and Slovenske Elektrarne.

Of course these numbers are part of the results I have already shown you in the previous charts. As you can see the installed capacity at 2007 is 3.1 gigawatts versus 2.6 of last year or plus 18.5%. And the production is equal to 11.8 gigawatt-hour versus 10.7 of last year. EBITDA totals €868 million versus €782 million with an increase of almost 11%.
In addition to this, we expect new capacity now in the pipeline to boost the profitability of our worldwide renewable operation as you will see later in the presentation of our accounts.
As far as our net debt evolution is concerned, on chart number 15, you'll see that the overall net debt stands at €57.5 billion including the net debt related to Endesa Europa for €1.7 billion.

The debt recorded an increase of €45.8 billion on 2006, mainly due to the acquisition of 67% of Endesa and 37% of OGK-5. Operational cash flow remains strong at €9.1 billion. We covered CapEx for €5.2 billion and paid interest of €1.4 billion. Regarding the debt structure as of 2007, we have refinanced €10 billion of our syndicated loan thanks to the issuance of bonds in euro, pound sterling and US dollar.

We have included in the annexes some slides with more details on our debt profile, but two points, are worth highlighting here. First, following our recent successful bond issue, the average maturity of our debt portfolio is over five years. The next falling due maturity will be three years from now as you can see chart number 119 in the annexes. Second, almost 50% of this debt is either fixed or hedged; we are therefore very satisfied with the stable and conservative structure of our debt profile.

And now dividend, as you know yesterday the Board of Directors resolved upon proposing to the AGM a €0.29 dividend per share that will be paid in June 26 this year as planned. This adds up to €0.20 interim dividend per share already paid in November 2007 for a total 2007 dividend of €0.49 per share. This makes Enel stock one of the European best-in-class, in terms of yield delivered to shareholders.
The solid financial performance, coupled with the resulting dividend, confirm that the ongoing strategy has delivered the expected results.
Thank you. And now I'll handover to Fulvio Conti for an overall view of the strategy.

Well, let me go back to 2006 and '07 just for a while. As you might remember, in my first strategy presentation back in March, 2006, I laid out a clear path for Enel with three key priorities: maintaining leadership in the Italian market; international growth, both organic and through acquisitions; and improved performance through investments and greater efficiencies.

This strategy has been followed through 2007 – add the environmental innovation program to complete our range of investor developments. The strength of these subtle numbers that Luigi has just reported to you, I think demonstrates that we are maintaining our leadership in the Italian market which continues to have attractive fundamentals.

We are delivering value from efficiency improvements across the Group. And during 2007, through the acquisition of Endesa and OGK-5 in Russia, we have achieved international growth which brings us an entirely new platform for future growth. Moreover, we are profiting on our renewables and innovation as you will see later during the presentation.

The phase of this transformational growth through large acquisition is over. Enel's strategy over the next five years will focus on delivering growth and value from our expanded portfolio. First we will ensure that the assets of Endesa and OGK-5 are successfully consolidated.
Second, we will capitalize on our leadership position in our core markets, such as Spain, Italy and Latin America.
Third, we will further increase our integration from upstream to downstream and complete the value chain in distribution and generation where we're missing one of those.
Fourth, we will continue to drive operational improvement programs throughout the Group, delivering significant further cost reductions.
Fifth, we're strongly focused on building growth in emerging areas, such as renewables and nuclear, both of which I will address in more detail.

As far as Endesa is concerned, I'm pleased to report that cooperation is proceeding well and we already established a close working relationship with Acciona. The synergies we will be delivering from this transaction are substantial.

They total about 730 million which is 50 million more than what we had announced in December, as we have found more in Latin America to be extracted. Endesa enjoys a strong established position to grow from in Iberia and Lat. Am.

Latin America, in particular, is one of the fastest growing energy markets in the entire world due to its tight supply and demand balance. Both geographies offer further growth potential through investments in incremental capacity, or by investments which upgrade existing facilities.
In Iberia further investments in CCGT plants will result in a more competitive and cleaner generation mix and wholesale retail gas markets offer significant growth potential.
In Latin America Endesa will invest both in generation capacity and distribution to capitalize on the growth of those markets.

Turning to Russia, I would like to update you on the progress we have made in this country. It is another region which offers very high potential for growth. We've been in Russia since 2004 as you know. And this experience has given us a clear view of the country's opportunity both in terms of demand growth and the progress of market liberalization.

The acquisition we have completed both in the upstream gas sector and in the power generation sector enables us to be a vertically integrated presence from upstream to downstream. Indeed the first ever integrated gas and power operator in that huge market.

Our joint venture with Eni in Russia will satisfy over 50% of OGK-5 gas needs starting with first gas in 2010. So far we have invested €4 billion in Russia including the total equity investments. We intent to invest further 2.2 billion over the next five years in developing our business both in power generation and upstream gas. Investments in OGK-5 will be both expansion of new CCGT and replacement of older capacity. Let's turn now into our business mix.

We have – Enel has a well balanced mix of fuel and the unregulated and regulated activities breakdown is solid. The regulated activities are in countries which have a clear and stable regulatory scenario. The group continues to have a well diversified fuel mix with 37.5% of generation coming from the combination of nuclear, hydro and other renewables. And this will provide us a sound platform for higher margins over the long-term. Not only, this will hedge our competitive position also against any negative carbon market scenario.

Beyond 2012 our production, our production mix will benefit from our additional nuclear capacity namely in France with EPR projects in association with EDF. We are going to get sizable position and in Slovakia with the completion of the two nuclear units of Slovenske Elektrarne which is ongoing.

Our earnings in generation are also enhanced by our strong forward contracting strategy. As a matter of fact we have substantially fully hedged Italy for 2008, Slovakia for almost 50%, as well as Iberia. For 2009 we have covered more than 50% of our sales and almost 40% in Iberia, and we are also selling into 2010 as the matter of fact already we have a sizable position in Iberia. We're 20% locked in. Let's move on.

Our growing international presence is giving us a platform for further strengthening into a vertical integration. In terms of gas inputs into Italy the supply agreement we secured with Algeria will give us an additional 1 billion cubic meters starting from 2009 thus reaching a total of 7 billion cubic meters. Together with the existing arrangements we have with LNG supplies from Nigeria and Qatar, we will reach total portfolio, 12 billion cubic meters per year.

Our participation into the Algerian, Italian and the GALSI project which will secure an additional 2 billion cubic meters per year on a long-term basis with first gas coming by 2012 will reinforce this position. As well as our development of LNG we are promoting obviously re-gasification units into Italy. We are very close to get a final permit on the re-gasify unit in with re-gasification capacity of 8 billion cubic meters eventually.

Let me speak about renewable. Let me focus your attention on this. Renewables will play a very important part of our future of Enel. Across all of our markets there are strong conditions for growth through incentive schemes to support this development of green energy. Therefore, we're starting up the development of our renewables in two main ways. First we are investing for growth. During the period of plan up to 2012 we will be investing a total of about €7 billion in this area to increase outlook from wind, mini-hydro and geothermal across all of our geographies.

We continue to invest in new technology such as the concentrated solar power with projects such as the Archimedes project in Sicily. The second way is that we will bundle all of these businesses into one single division across all geographies and technologies. There will be additional value to be extracted by managing all of our renewables business as one single unit sharing innovation and best practices, procurement synergies and overall management efficiencies. Also we will not stop by 2012. There will be lot of pipeline projects moving beyond 2012, which will be instigated by this new division.

Obviously one of our key aims is the one of developing long-term growth through a well balanced and diversified generation portfolio. And nuclear in this context will play a major role and it will be an important feature of our generation mix. Nuclear provides important balance with its all – low cost and low emission characteristics.

Today we have running about 4000 megawatts of capacity and we plan to grow further this with these projects in France and Russia and Slovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. From 2008, Enel will participate in the International Research and Development work for at least one of the plans of fourth generation technology. We are already partnering with EDF in France in the development of the next generation European pressurized reactor technology with the plant Flamanville.

And to the extent we have signed an agreement with Rosatom the Russian energy – the atomic energy group we will be pursuing co-development opportunities in the Eastern parts of Europe. As well as we are looking at the Cernavoda Romanian plant. Possibly we've might have lost the Bulgarian bid without regrets.

Our investment program demonstrates, we are committed to invest in further growth. We are investing 37 billion, but the important feature of this is more than 21 billion is specially focused on organic growth. This investment flow will reach the peak over the next three years and then will be reduced significantly in 2012 when bulk of our organic growth will be completed. And at that point in time the group will turn into a highly cash generative company.

Alongside with this program for growth, we are developing a strategy of portfolio optimization. We have identified opportunities to realize value from some of our assets. First, as you know we are about to complete the assets which have been agreed with the antitrust authorities to be sold to E.ON as part of the Endesa transaction. We will continue to look into the disposals of high voltage network, the residual portion of high voltage network in Italy, which is on well on track for being completed by the end of 2008.

We also intend to realize the value that we're generating from the incorporation into one single unit of the renewable businesses. This could take some different forms. It will depend on the market that will also be our option to select the appropriate route while maintaining the majority stake in what we've been building so far.

We are also providing – we're also gathering for some limited resources, if there is a scenario for any opportunistic minor development, which if conditions and terms are compelling could be realized. But the overall mix that will be available to fund debt reduction is sizeable. Now you will see the details of the presentation, our colleagues here they will give you the basis for which I presented to you such evolutionary and positive plan. Thank you.
Who is next, Francesco?

Good morning everybody. Let me start with a quick overview. Can you hear me? Okay, Right. Let me give you a little bit of an overview of our strategic priorities for the next five years. We have and we remain to be – we remain the leader of – in the regulated market. We have become and we will continue to grow our leadership in the free electricity and gas market. This is the way to enhance control throughout the whole value chain and protect the group margin. We aim to reach operational excellence in particular; we want to improve within our customer base the perception of the quality of our services.

Let's now go on and see how we look at the electricity market in Italy over the next five years. What you see here is a representation of the evolution of the market between 2006 and 2012. We expect growth in demand throughout this period with a compound annual growth rate of around 2% in the period. From the 1st of July 2007 the existing market in Italy is fully opened. Which means that all customer segments including the residential one can choose the supplier both for electricity and gas.

Our sales strategy for the retail market is based on a very simple fixed price Dual Energy offer with a strong attention to renewable energy. Free market growth has been 12.3% from 2006 to 2007 and our estimate is a 17% growth from 2007 to 2008. Enel has been the driving force behind this growth of the free market and let's see this in a little bit more detail in the next slide.

This is quite a busy chart, let me guide you thought it. At the end of 2007 the number of customers in the free market has reached a total of 2.7 million this is a 300% growth in terms of customers and an additional 19 terawatt hour consumption in the free market due to our strong efforts which started in spring 2006. Out of this 2.7 million our share is 1.7, the rest of the competition has 1 million all together. This makes us by far the leading player in the Italian retail market.

Now, let's look this more in detail. Let's begin with the business segment. At the end of 2006, in the business segment we had only 700,000 customers. They consume 154.4 terawatt hours. At the end of the year 2007, only Enel has reached 1.1 million customers with a portfolio of 56 terawatt hours. On the residential segment, since the 1st of July, 2007 at the end with a beginning of the liberalization of all the residential customers, the mass has reached the 33 million of eligible clients. We have been the first Italian operator, who launched a Dual Energy offer for the residential customer. We switched in the last semester of 2007 more than 600,000 customers. We believe the combined effort of our competitors will add another 100,000 at the year end.

We are currently offering our residential clients renewable product – renewable fixed price energy and a two years fixed price for gas too. Considering the situation in the commodities market these products have been very successful. We had quite an insight in putting them on the market early enough during the first part of 2008 so when we are talking we are progressing at the rate of 10,000 contracts a day considering all segments so it's quite a strong push.

Now on the gas market we had a pulse in gas demand in 2006 due to climate effect. We continue to forecast a moderate but steady growth between 2007 and 2012 approximately at 1.6% per annum. It is because Italy already has a very high penetration of gas distribution throughout the country. Growth will therefore come only from organic growth of society from existing customers and is expected to be split equally between domestic and business segment.

What we can say we observed a renewed interest in retail gas switching as a result of the full liberalization of the electricity market. So I think that gas has been pushed back into fashion after the liberalization of the electricity market and our dual energy strategy proves this. In the first six months more than 200,000 residential customers joined our dual energy offer. Let's focus now on our position in these markets.

What is our aim? Our aim is to push growth on a selected customer basis. Growth in terms of volume sold to the electricity market to a well selected portfolio of free customers with the aim to match our optimal production mix. This will lead us to place about 100 almost 97 terawatt hours on the electricity free market by 2012.

Growth in terms of volumes sold to the gas market. We constantly tap our gas and electricity dual energy offering. This is based growing our volumes in this market up to 9.2 billion cubic meters by 2012. Where are we at the end of 2007? We have about 4.5 million customers in both markets, 1.6 million only electricity, 2.6 million only gas, 209,000 dual energy. To be more specific on the portfolio of customers what you can see in this chart is a representation of this ideal optimum portfolio of customers that we are well underway to assemble. The combination of clients from all segments brings the total to 14 million on the free markets, of which over 3.6 million will be dual energy. With an overall combined consumption profile so these 14 million customers will absorb our energy in a way that matches well our optimal production profile in the expected evolution of the Italian energy market.

We will also have 1.8 million gas only customers at the end of the period. Now a little bit of a snapshot on forward sales which are an evergreen of these presentations. We have sold 100% as you heard from Fulvio of 2008 production. Of this 69.3 terawatt hours have delivered already to the free market and the balance with a single buyer and other traders. At the end of 2007 we have already sold 53.2 terawatt hours and another 31.8 are sold throughout 2010. We are progressing with a monthly pace of 1.8 terawatt hours a month with a two years rolling forward time horizon more than 85% of the actual volumes have sold at fixed price.

And now let's have a quick look at the development of the solar photovoltaic energy sector, as you know Italy today is one of the hottest markets in this sector. We have a favorable incentive scheme and the market is literally booming. In the last years we have begun to develop our presence in the energy efficiency and renewable sectors on the retail end. We are offering with these brands product for all segments of clients in particular in the field of renewable distributed generation. So photovoltaic, solar energy, thermal solar energy, many ways.

How we do this? We have a grid of qualified franchising solars, it's a network of more than 310 dealers which we are growing constantly. They are located throughout Italy they cater for the retail and small business market and we have a central engineering unit for large installations.

Currently we hold 34% of the photovoltaic market in the country in terms of capacity sold and installed to third parties in the next five years we want to grow our percentage more than the market growth. So we have an objective of having 210 megawatts of solar photovoltaic power installed and a market share of 42% by 2012.

We think in Italy we will be one of the first countries where we will achieve grid parity between cost generated for peak hours and cost generated by photovoltaic fuel cells. It's a combination of a lot of interesting factors in this country, and we are pursuing a strategy for a long term alliance with the world leaders in this technology upstream in the silicon value chain to sustain our presence after 2012.

Now I focus on cost to serve. As the number of customers on the electricity and dual energy market grows as you see and as we keep introducing new steam-lined processes and new IT applications our interest in dual energy free market cost to serve will decrease, it's actually already going down. We plan to reach a target of €23 per customer cost levering in 2012. We are targeting a free customer base of 14 million by 2012.

This is free customers, at the same time we will also be handling around 15 million customers that one way or another will have decided or not decided but will remain on the regulated market. Therefore we will be at this point handling around 30 million customers. We'll be managing one of the largest client's bases in the world. We leverage this cost competitiveness on this very large base and we we'll export this know how elsewhere in our European base.

Now, as small snapshot on the acquisition cost, of course, increasing the number of customers in this free electricity and gas market has a cost. We are driving down the acquisition costs and our objective is to push this single customer acquisition cost down from €50 per customer in 2007, to €29 per customer by 2012. This is through some drivers. The optimization of the channel mix by using less costly channels, for example, wholesale. Development an increase of virtual channels, which already start to give us a lot of satisfaction like a website and basically enhance our capabilities to extract synergies via progressive implementation of advanced geo-marketing tools and competitive market simulations.
I thank you very much. I hand now over Gianfilippo Mancini, to take you through our strategy and target for the Generation and Energy Management Division. Gianfilippo?

Thank you, Francesco. And good morning ladies and gentlemen. Our strong domestic leadership is founded on a competitive and flexible generation fleet, on our operational excellence and our well focused fuel and power commercial capabilities. We believe we can further leverage on these resources in order to achieve our ambitious target of operational excellence and profitability.

Before I move to describe in more detail these actions, let's have a look at the market scenario now. As you can see here, in 2007, CCGT production reached almost 50% of the Italian energy mix. This specific situation of dependency of generation cost upon gas prices will continue in the future, as additional CCGTs will enter the market. This will reinforce the dependence of the Italian wholesale prices on the cost structure of the CCGTs.

Let now focus on our investment plan. This is core in our long-term strategy and will allow us to strengthen our leadership in the Italian market to expose new opportunities and to face environmental challenges. Our Italian program is on track. As for CCGTs in 2007, we completed our five gigawatt conversion program with the commissioning of the last unit at .

In order to further improve our CCGTs' flexibility, we've launched a new investment program that will enable these plant to work at profitably at lower load levels, while also increasing their maximum output.

This will provide us to with approximately 200 megawatts of additional capacity. Also additional, oil and gas power plant still play an important role in our portfolio strategy too. But thanks to their flexibility, which allows us to capture significant opportunities in the ancillary services market and in exports.

In coal, our new plant will contribute to dramatically lowering our production cost with raising our base load volumes of production. With respect to Torre Nord, we confirm that the first unit will be in full operation during 2008, while the other two units will follow in 2009. This new, clean coal, state of the art power plant will represent a world benchmark in terms both of efficiency and of environmental impact.

Referring to Porto Tolle we are awaiting national environmental impact assessment before starting construction phase for which we expect we will leverage on the experience gathered from the similar Torre Nord projects. With current oil prices we also perceive an increased interest in clean coal which makes us confident that we will achieve authorization before year end.

We're also implementing specific investment programs dedicated to our existing programs, which will give us both a significant environmental improvement on pulverized coal capture and coal logistic and an additional 100 megawatts of output free of fuel costs.

Now let's move to renewables. Here we are pursuing new opportunities and increasing our 2008-2012 investment program as you can see here. With this new program we'll be investing more than €3 billion in development and maintenance project with an increased target in additional installed capacity by 2012 of 1.4 gigawatt, most of which in wind. This target is based on a large and strong portfolio of initiatives and it will give us a return over 14% in IRR thanks to a positive Italian regulatory regime on green certificates.

On the wind sector we are developing projects in excess of 4 gigawatt, mainly in the windy areas of Southern Italy and we are pushing forward this initiative through specific agreements with local authorities leveraging on our presence in these territories. As an example of this, we recently have signed an agreement with Sardinia region to build 160 megawatt, new wind plant that will be online before the next year end.

Regarding geothermal production as you know we are the world leaders in this sector and we have recently signed an agreement with Tuscany region to develop new plants for a total of 200 megawatts. And finally moving to hydro our consolidated technical expertise and the extent of our portfolio of assets allows us to carryout several green-certificate projects at high return. We are revamping our existing plants and we are developing new, small hydro projects thus increasing by one terawatt hour our profitable green certificate production by 2012.

Moving now to research and innovation activities, we are focused in particular on improving fossil fuel power efficiency and on CCS projects. Our aim here is to acquire experience in all technologies connected to the capture and the storage of CO2 after positive results of our first research activities, pilot plants for pulse combustion and oxy-combustion technologies in our existing plant at Brindisi are currently in the authorization phase.

The first pulse combustion demo plants will be located in one of our high efficiency coal plants in Torre Nord or Porto Tolle. And regarding our hydrogen pilot plant the 12 megawatt plant at Fusina is currently under construction. And we're also developing investments for innovation in renewables in particular in thermodynamic solar with the Archimedes project in concentrated photovoltaic technology and in geothermal energy.

Our investment plan is driven by the awareness that the power business today, CO2 constraints and emission limits will be even tighter in the future. In this regard our new clean coal units will be more competitive than combined cycle turbines even assuming very high CO2 prices.
The variable costs described in this chart imply that only with CO2 prices above €70 per ton given the commodities forward pricing we see today, will CCGTs be as competitive as our clean coal units.

With this respect, the new 2008-2012 Italian National Allocation Plan is contributing to define a more predictable scenario. We now expect a unit shortage of around 8 to 9 million tons between 2008 and 2012.
